etymologies: Middle English pentis (in penthouse (sense 2)), shortening of Old French apentis, based on late Latin appendicium ‘appendage’, from Latin appendere ‘hang on’. The change of form in the 16th century was by association with French pente ‘slope’ and house

definitions: an apartment on the top floor of a tall building, typically luxuriously fitted and offering fine views.
shortDefinitions: flat on top floor of tall building

definitions: an outhouse or shelter built onto the side of a building, having a sloping roof.
shortDefinitions: outhouse or shelter with sloping roof, built on to side of building
